moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4: My opponent plays the King's Gambit, indicating a desire for a wide-open game.
moves.2... exf4: I am a gentleman. I always either accept the gambit, as I do here, or offer the Falkbeer Counter-Gambit (2... P-Q4).
moves.5... Qh4+: One cannot be passive on the Black side of the King's Gambit. Counter-attack is the order of the day.
moves.6... Qf2+: I am hoping to induce an exchange of Queens.
moves.7... Nf6: An attack by a single piece is virtually always doomed to fail. Instead of snatching the Pawn I develop.
moves.8. Nc3: White adds another piece to the fray.
moves.9... d6: I force a retreat and open a line for my Bishop to come out.
moves.10. Rf1: Rather than retreat immediately, White attacks the Q.
moves.10... Qxg2: Now, since I have to move it anyway, I do take the Pawn.
moves.11. Nc4: Forced to avoid losing the piece.
moves.11... Qh3+: Removing the defense of the KP.
moves.12... Nxe4+: Adding another piece to the attack.
moves.13... Qh4+: White resigns, as the continuation would be 14 R-K2 QxR mate.
